questions.question: To qualify for head of household filing status, which of the following is NOT required?

options.A: The taxpayer must be unmarried at year-end
options.B: The taxpayer must pay more than half the cost of maintaining a household
options.C: A qualifying person must live with the taxpayer for the entire year
options.D: The home must be the principal residence of a qualifying person

questions.explanation: A qualifying child must live with the taxpayer for more than half the year, not the entire year. A qualifying relative parent does not need to live with the taxpayer at all. The taxpayer must be unmarried (or considered unmarried) at year-end and pay more than half the cost of maintaining the household.
questions.tip: For head of household, a dependent parent doesn't need to live with you - you just need to pay over half their household costs.

questions.question: Long-term capital gains from the sale of collectibles are taxed at a maximum rate of:
questions.explanation: Long-term capital gains from collectibles (art, antiques, stamps, coins, gems, most metals) are taxed at a maximum rate of 28%. This is higher than the preferential 0%/15%/20% rates that apply to most other long-term capital gains.
questions.tip: Remember: Collectibles and Section 1202 QSBS exclusion amounts are both taxed at 28% max rate.

questions.question: In a bilateral contract:

options.A: Only one party makes a promise
options.B: Both parties exchange promises
options.C: Acceptance can only be made by performance
options.D: The offeror can revoke after performance begins

questions.explanation: A bilateral contract involves an exchange of promises by both parties. Each party's promise serves as consideration for the other's promise. In contrast, a unilateral contract involves a promise in exchange for performance, where only the offeror makes a promise and the offeree accepts by performing the requested act.
questions.tip: Bilateral = both promise; Unilateral = one promises, other performs.

questions.question: Under the required taxable year rules, a partnership must generally use:

options.A: A calendar year
options.B: The tax year of its majority interest partners
options.C: Any fiscal year elected by the partners
options.D: The tax year that results in the least aggregate deferral

questions.explanation: Partnerships must use the tax year of their majority interest partners (partners owning more than 50% of capital and profits). If there is no majority interest, the partnership uses the tax year of all principal partners. If principal partners have different years, the partnership uses the year resulting in the least aggregate deferral.
questions.tip: Partnership year rule priority: (1) Majority interest, (2) Principal partners, (3) Least aggregate deferral.

questions.question: Under Circular 230, a tax practitioner may represent conflicting interests if:

options.A: Both clients provide written informed consent
options.B: The practitioner believes they can competently represent both
options.D: Conflicts of interest are never permitted

questions.explanation: Under Circular 230, a practitioner may represent conflicting interests before the IRS only if: (1) the practitioner reasonably believes they can provide competent and diligent representation to each client, and (2) each affected client provides informed consent in writing. Both conditions must be satisfied.
questions.tip: Circular 230 conflict rules mirror legal ethics - competent belief + written consent from all.

questions.question: When a principal's conduct causes a third party to reasonably believe an agent has authority, this creates:

options.A: Express authority
options.B: Implied authority
options.D: Ratification

questions.explanation: Apparent authority arises when the principal's conduct leads a third party to reasonably believe the agent has authority to act. It is based on the third party's reasonable perception, not actual authority granted. Express authority is explicitly stated, implied authority is reasonably necessary to carry out express authority, and ratification is after-the-fact approval.
questions.tip: Apparent authority focuses on what the third party reasonably believes based on the principal's actions.

questions.question: Under a divorce decree executed in 2020, Tom pays his ex-wife $2,000 per month in alimony. How should Tom treat these payments for tax purposes?

options.A: Deductible for AGI
options.B: Deductible from AGI as an itemized deduction
options.D: Deductible as a personal exemption

questions.explanation: For divorce or separation agreements executed after December 31, 2018, alimony payments are not deductible by the payor and not includible in income by the recipient. The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act eliminated the alimony deduction for agreements executed after 2018. Tom's 2020 divorce decree falls under these new rules.
questions.tip: Post-2018 divorces: Alimony is not deductible by payor and not taxable to recipient.

questions.question: The accumulated earnings tax applies when a corporation accumulates earnings beyond reasonable business needs primarily to:

options.A: Expand plant facilities
options.B: Acquire another business
options.D: Provide for product liability contingencies

questions.explanation: The accumulated earnings tax (AET) is a penalty tax imposed on corporations that accumulate earnings beyond reasonable business needs for the purpose of avoiding the income tax that would be imposed on shareholders if dividends were distributed. Legitimate business purposes for accumulation (expansion, acquisition, contingencies) do not trigger the tax.
questions.tip: AET targets tax avoidance intent. Document legitimate business reasons for retaining earnings.

questions.question: In Year 6, a taxpayer has a $50,000 net Section 1231 gain. In Years 1-5, the taxpayer had a total of $30,000 in net Section 1231 losses that were deducted as ordinary losses. How is the Year 6 gain characterized?

options.A: $50,000 long-term capital gain
options.B: $30,000 ordinary income and $20,000 long-term capital gain
options.D: $30,000 long-term capital gain and $20,000 ordinary income

questions.explanation: The Section 1231 lookback rule requires net Section 1231 gains to be treated as ordinary income to the extent of non-recaptured Section 1231 losses from the prior 5 years. The $30,000 of prior losses converts $30,000 of the current gain to ordinary income. The remaining $20,000 is treated as long-term capital gain.
questions.tip: Section 1231 lookback recaptures prior ordinary loss treatment - prevents manipulation between ordinary loss and capital gain.

questions.question: To achieve super-priority status, a purchase money security interest (PMSI) in inventory must be perfected:

options.A: Within 20 days of debtor receiving possession
options.B: Before the debtor receives possession of the inventory
options.D: At any time before the debtor defaults

questions.explanation: A PMSI in inventory must be perfected BEFORE the debtor receives possession of the inventory, and the secured party must send notification to holders of conflicting security interests who have filed financing statements. This is stricter than PMSI in equipment, which allows 20 days after possession for perfection.
questions.tip: PMSI timing: Equipment = 20 days AFTER possession; Inventory = BEFORE possession + notify existing creditors.

questions.question: After an S corporation election terminates, during the post-termination transition period (PTTP), shareholders may:

options.A: Continue to increase stock basis for income
options.B: Deduct suspended losses against distributions
options.C: Make additional capital contributions to restore basis
options.D: Elect to retain S corporation status

questions.explanation: During the PTTP (generally one year after the termination date), shareholders can deduct any suspended losses from the S corporation period to the extent of stock basis. However, they cannot increase basis during this period. The PTTP provides a limited window to utilize losses that were previously suspended due to insufficient basis.
questions.tip: PTTP is a one-year window after S termination to use suspended losses against stock basis only.

questions.question: Which of the following factors causes the Earned Income Credit to phase out?

options.A: Only earned income exceeding the threshold
options.B: Only AGI exceeding the threshold
options.C: The greater of earned income or AGI exceeding the threshold
options.D: The lesser of earned income or AGI exceeding the threshold

questions.explanation: The Earned Income Credit phases out based on the greater of earned income or AGI. This prevents taxpayers with low earned income but high investment income from receiving the credit. The credit is designed to benefit working individuals and families with lower total income.
questions.tip: EIC phase-out uses the GREATER of earned income or AGI - this prevents those with high investment income from qualifying.

questions.question: The Chapter 7 means test compares a debtor's income to:

options.A: The federal poverty level
options.B: The state median income for a similar household size
options.D: 150% of the federal minimum wage

questions.explanation: The Chapter 7 means test compares the debtor's current monthly income to the state median income for a household of the same size. If income exceeds the median, further calculations determine whether the debtor has sufficient disposable income to repay creditors under Chapter 13, potentially resulting in a presumption of abuse.
questions.tip: Means test = State median income comparison. Above median triggers additional calculations.

questions.question: A taxpayer sells property with an adjusted basis of $60,000 for $100,000, receiving $20,000 down and a note for $80,000. What is the gross profit percentage for installment sale reporting?
questions.explanation: The gross profit percentage equals gross profit divided by the contract price. Gross profit = $100,000 selling price - $60,000 basis = $40,000. Contract price = $100,000 (selling price with no assumed mortgage). Gross profit percentage = $40,000 / $100,000 = 40%. Each payment received is 40% gain and 60% return of basis.
questions.tip: Gross profit % = (Selling price - Basis) / Contract price. Apply this % to each payment received.

questions.question: Guaranteed payments to a partner for services are treated by the receiving partner as:

options.A: Self-employment income
options.B: Wages subject to withholding
options.D: Distributive share of partnership income

questions.explanation: Guaranteed payments for services are treated as self-employment income to the receiving partner. They are subject to self-employment tax and are not wages (so no income tax withholding). The partnership deducts guaranteed payments as a business expense, and they are separately stated on Schedule K-1.
questions.tip: Partners aren't employees - guaranteed payments = self-employment income, not wages.

questions.question: Under IRC Section 6662, substantial authority for a tax position is generally described as:

options.A: A greater than 50% likelihood of success
options.B: Approximately 40% likelihood of success
options.C: Any reasonable basis for the position
options.D: A position that would more likely than not be sustained

questions.explanation: Substantial authority is an objective standard that is more stringent than 'reasonable basis' (approximately 20%) but less stringent than 'more likely than not' (greater than 50%). It is generally considered to require approximately a 40% likelihood that the position would be sustained on its merits.
questions.tip: Tax position standards: Reasonable basis (~20%) < Substantial authority (~40%) < More likely than not (>50%).

questions.question: When a traditional IRA is converted to a Roth IRA, the converted amount is:

options.A: Not taxable until distribution from the Roth
options.B: Taxable as ordinary income in the year of conversion
options.D: Subject to the 10% early withdrawal penalty

questions.explanation: Converting a traditional IRA to a Roth IRA is a taxable event. The converted amount is included in ordinary income in the year of conversion. However, the 10% early withdrawal penalty does not apply to the converted amount (though the 5-year rule must be satisfied for tax-free withdrawal of converted amounts).
questions.tip: Roth conversion = taxable event but no 10% penalty on the conversion itself.

questions.question: Under UCC Article 4, a depositary bank must take action on a check by its:

options.A: Close of business on the day of receipt
options.B: Midnight deadline - midnight of the next banking day after receipt
options.D: Within 5 banking days of receipt

questions.explanation: Under UCC Article 4, the midnight deadline is midnight of the next banking day following the banking day on which the bank receives the relevant item or notice. A bank must take proper action (pay, return, or send notice) on items before this deadline or it becomes accountable for the item.
questions.tip: Midnight deadline = midnight of NEXT banking day after receipt. Miss it and the bank is liable.

questions.question: In a like-kind exchange, Taxpayer A exchanges property with an adjusted basis of $100,000 and FMV of $150,000 for like-kind property worth $130,000 plus $20,000 cash. What is the recognized gain?
questions.explanation: In a like-kind exchange, gain is recognized to the extent of boot received. Realized gain = $150,000 FMV given - $100,000 basis = $50,000. Boot received = $20,000 cash. Recognized gain is the lesser of realized gain ($50,000) or boot received ($20,000) = $20,000.
questions.tip: Boot forces gain recognition. Recognized gain = lesser of (realized gain, boot received).

questions.question: In a Section 351 exchange, a shareholder transfers property with a basis of $40,000 and FMV of $100,000 in exchange for stock worth $85,000 and cash of $15,000. The shareholder recognizes gain of:
questions.explanation: In a Section 351 exchange, gain is recognized to the extent of boot received. Realized gain = $100,000 FMV - $40,000 basis = $60,000. Boot received = $15,000 cash. Recognized gain = lesser of realized gain ($60,000) or boot ($15,000) = $15,000.
questions.tip: Section 351 boot rule mirrors like-kind exchanges: recognize lesser of realized gain or boot.

questions.question: Which of the following is an AMT adjustment or preference item?

options.A: Charitable contributions
options.B: Home mortgage interest on acquisition debt
options.C: Exercise of incentive stock options (excess of FMV over exercise price)
options.D: State income tax refund

questions.explanation: The exercise of incentive stock options (ISOs) creates an AMT adjustment equal to the excess of the stock's FMV over the exercise price at the date of exercise. This is a positive adjustment that increases AMTI. Charitable contributions and acquisition debt interest are allowed for both regular tax and AMT.
questions.tip: ISO exercise is the most common AMT preference item - the bargain element is taxable for AMT.

questions.question: When an agent acts for an undisclosed principal and the third party later discovers the principal's identity, the third party may generally:

options.A: Only sue the agent
options.B: Only sue the principal
options.C: Sue either the agent or the principal, but must elect one
options.D: Sue both the agent and principal simultaneously

questions.explanation: When an undisclosed principal is later discovered, the third party may elect to hold either the agent or the principal liable, but generally must elect one. This election doctrine prevents the third party from recovering twice. Once the third party obtains a judgment against one, the third party cannot pursue the other.
questions.tip: Undisclosed principal discovered = third party elects agent OR principal, not both.

questions.question: Distributable net income (DNI) serves all of the following purposes EXCEPT:

options.A: Determining the maximum deduction available to the estate or trust
options.B: Determining the maximum amount taxable to beneficiaries
options.C: Determining the character of distributions to beneficiaries
options.D: Determining the estate or trust's applicable tax rate

questions.explanation: DNI serves three key functions: (1) limits the distribution deduction for the estate/trust, (2) caps the amount taxable to beneficiaries, and (3) determines the character of income in beneficiaries' hands. It does not determine the applicable tax rate, which is based on the estate/trust tax brackets.
questions.tip: DNI has three purposes: cap trust deduction, cap beneficiary income, preserve character.

questions.question: Father sells stock with a basis of $50,000 to his daughter for $30,000 (FMV). Daughter later sells the stock for $55,000. What is Daughter's recognized gain or loss?

options.A: $5,000 gain

questions.explanation: Father's $20,000 loss is disallowed under Section 267 related party rules. Daughter's basis is her cost of $30,000. When Daughter sells for $55,000, she has a $25,000 potential gain. However, she can use Father's disallowed loss to offset gain, reducing gain to $5,000 ($55,000 - $30,000 - $20,000 used from disallowed loss = $5,000).
questions.tip: Related party disallowed loss becomes buyer's offset - but only against gain, never to create a loss.

questions.question: Under Circular 230, best practices for tax advisors include all of the following EXCEPT:

options.A: Communicating clearly with the client regarding terms of engagement
options.B: Establishing relevant facts and evaluating the reasonableness of assumptions
options.C: Guaranteeing specific tax outcomes to clients
options.D: Advising clients of the importance of conclusions reached

questions.explanation: Circular 230 Section 10.33 describes best practices including clear communication, establishing facts, evaluating assumptions, applying law, and advising clients of conclusions. Guaranteeing specific tax outcomes would be inappropriate as tax positions may be challenged, and outcomes depend on IRS interpretation and audit selection.
questions.tip: Never guarantee tax outcomes - tax law involves interpretation and audit risk.

questions.question: A Section 754 election allows a partnership to:

options.A: Convert to S corporation status
options.B: Adjust the basis of partnership assets upon certain triggering events
options.D: Elect out of Subchapter K

questions.explanation: A Section 754 election allows a partnership to adjust the basis of partnership assets following a transfer of a partnership interest (Section 743(b)) or a distribution of property (Section 734(b)). This prevents new partners from inheriting built-in gains or losses in partnership assets.
questions.tip: Section 754 = optional basis adjustment election. Benefits incoming partners who pay premium for appreciated assets.

questions.question: To qualify as a real estate professional and avoid passive activity limitations, a taxpayer must satisfy which requirements?

options.A: More than 50% of personal services in real property trades and more than 500 hours of material participation
options.B: More than 50% of personal services in real property trades and more than 750 hours in real property trades
options.C: More than 750 hours in rental real estate and material participation in each rental activity
options.D: Both B and material participation in each rental activity (or election to aggregate)

questions.explanation: Real estate professional status requires: (1) more than 50% of personal services performed in real property trades or businesses, (2) more than 750 hours in real property trades or businesses, AND (3) material participation in each rental activity (unless the taxpayer elects to treat all interests as a single activity). All three requirements must be met.
questions.tip: Real estate professional = 50%+ time in real estate + 750+ hours + material participation in each rental (or aggregate election).

questions.question: Under Section 11 of the Securities Act of 1933, which party cannot assert a due diligence defense?

options.A: Directors
options.B: Underwriters
options.D: Accountants certifying financial statements

questions.explanation: Under Section 11, the issuer has strict liability for material misstatements or omissions in the registration statement and cannot assert a due diligence defense. Directors, underwriters, and experts (including accountants for portions they certified) can avoid liability by proving they conducted reasonable investigation and had reasonable grounds to believe statements were true.
questions.tip: Issuer = strict liability under Section 11. Everyone else can claim due diligence defense.

questions.question: An S corporation converted from C corporation status. At conversion, Asset X had a basis of $100,000 and FMV of $250,000. Three years later (within the recognition period), the S corporation sells Asset X for $300,000. What is the built-in gain subject to the built-in gains tax?
questions.explanation: The built-in gains tax applies to the lesser of: (1) recognized gain ($300,000 - $100,000 = $200,000) or (2) built-in gain at conversion ($250,000 - $100,000 = $150,000). The $50,000 appreciation after conversion is not subject to BIG tax. Therefore, $150,000 is the built-in gain subject to corporate-level tax.
questions.tip: BIG tax only reaches gain existing at C-to-S conversion. Post-conversion appreciation passes through tax-free.

questions.question: A married taxpayer filing jointly invested $150,000 for original issue Section 1244 stock. The stock became worthless. What is the tax treatment of the loss?

options.A: $150,000 ordinary loss
options.B: $100,000 ordinary loss and $50,000 capital loss
options.D: $150,000 capital loss

questions.explanation: Section 1244 allows ordinary loss treatment on qualifying small business stock, but the deduction is limited to $100,000 per year for married filing jointly ($50,000 for other filers). The excess $50,000 is treated as a capital loss. Section 1244 must be original issue stock (not purchased in secondary market).
questions.tip: Section 1244 ordinary loss limit: $100,000 MFJ, $50,000 others. Excess becomes capital loss.

questions.question: In Chapter 11 bankruptcy, a 'cramdown' occurs when:

options.A: The debtor converts the case to Chapter 7
options.B: The court confirms a plan over the objection of an impaired class
options.D: The debtor rejects an executory contract

questions.explanation: A cramdown allows the bankruptcy court to confirm a Chapter 11 reorganization plan even though an impaired class of creditors has not accepted it. For cramdown, the plan must not discriminate unfairly, be fair and equitable to the dissenting class, and at least one impaired class must accept the plan.
questions.tip: Cramdown = court forces plan on dissenting creditors. Requires 'fair and equitable' treatment and no unfair discrimination.

questions.question: In a service partnership, liquidating payments to a retiring general partner for goodwill (where the partnership agreement is silent on goodwill) are treated as:

options.A: Section 736(b) payments - distributions for partnership interest
options.B: Section 736(a) payments - ordinary income to the partner
options.D: Tax-free distributions

questions.explanation: In a service partnership, if the partnership agreement does not provide for goodwill payments, payments for unstated goodwill are treated as Section 736(a) payments - either guaranteed payments or distributive share. These are ordinary income to the retiring partner and deductible by the partnership. If goodwill is stated in the agreement, it's treated as Section 736(b).
questions.tip: Service partnership silent on goodwill = Section 736(a) ordinary income. Stated goodwill = Section 736(b) capital.

questions.question: The Section 965 transition tax, enacted as part of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, applied to:

options.A: Future earnings of controlled foreign corporations
options.B: Accumulated post-1986 deferred foreign income of specified foreign corporations
options.C: All foreign source income of U.S. shareholders
options.D: Only passive foreign investment company distributions

questions.explanation: Section 965 imposed a one-time transition tax on the accumulated post-1986 deferred foreign income of specified foreign corporations, deemed repatriated in the last tax year before January 1, 2018. This was part of the transition to the territorial tax system. Cash assets were taxed at 15.5% and non-cash at 8%.
questions.tip: Section 965 = one-time 'toll charge' on accumulated offshore earnings (15.5% cash, 8% non-cash) as transition to territorial system.

questions.question: Taxpayer sells stock at a $10,000 loss on December 15. On December 28, the taxpayer purchases a call option on substantially identical stock. The wash sale rule:

options.A: Does not apply because options are not stock
options.B: Applies - the loss is disallowed and added to the option's basis
options.C: Applies only if the option is exercised
options.D: Does not apply because options cannot be substantially identical

questions.explanation: The wash sale rule applies to purchases of substantially identical stock OR securities, including options to acquire substantially identical stock. Purchasing a call option within 30 days before or after selling stock at a loss triggers the wash sale rule. The disallowed loss is added to the basis of the replacement position (the option).
questions.tip: Wash sale rule covers options too. Buying calls/puts on same stock within 61-day window disallows the loss.

questions.question: In a consolidated return, when a subsidiary sells appreciated property to the parent corporation, the gain is:

options.A: Recognized immediately by the subsidiary
options.B: Deferred until the property is sold outside the consolidated group
options.D: Split between the parent and subsidiary

questions.explanation: Under the consolidated return regulations, gain or loss on intercompany transactions is deferred until a corresponding event occurs, typically when the property leaves the consolidated group through sale to an outsider. This matching principle ensures the consolidated group is taxed as if it were a single entity.
questions.tip: Consolidated returns defer intercompany gains/losses until the asset leaves the group - single entity concept.
